entry.title: Combined summary - Preparing for the Cryptopocalypse
entry.summary: The discussion about the suitability of different cryptographic techniques for Bitcoin is ongoing. TRU has been deemed unsuitable due to its poor performance in bandwidth and space usage. Lamport signatures have been suggested as an alternative, but they also have similar issues. The comparison between ECDLP and RSA/factoring problems in light of quantum computing is a topic of debate. While ECC is considered more secure than RSA, there are doubts about its superiority from a quantum computing standpoint. Post-quantum schemes based on Regev's LWE assumption are becoming more competitive with traditional schemes, but they also have their own concerns.A presentation shared by Melvin Carvalho provides a comprehensive overview of cryptography, including its history, modern cryptographic techniques, and practical applications. The presentation covers topics such as secure email communication, messaging, file sharing, and online payments. It also discusses popular tools and protocols used for these purposes, such as PGP, OTR, Tor, and Bitcoin. Despite the advances in cryptography, there are still many questions beyond cryptography that need to be addressed.In a conversation with an unknown person, Peter Vessenes discusses the possibility of using NTRU, a lattice-based algorithm recommended by NIST, on Bitcoin. Although the NTRUsign algorithm to produce signatures was broken last year, Vessenes believes that it could still be acceptable for Bitcoin as long as only one signature is created per key. He also suggests that there are always alternatives such as Lamport signatures if NTRUsign is ever broken. In an email exchange, Vessenes discusses the security of digital signature schemes with a colleague and notes that Lamport signatures are simpler, faster, and intuitively secure under both classical and quantum computation. However, Lamport signatures have poor space/bandwidth usage properties which make them unsuitable for use in Bitcoin. Vessenes also questions the claim that elliptic curve cryptography (ECC) is significantly more secure than RSA, but he acknowledges that ECC is typically used with smaller keys and is considered the maximally hard case of its problem class. Nonetheless, Vessenes worries about breakthroughs that could give index-calculus level performance for general elliptic curves.An HTML attachment has been scrubbed in the context provided, but no further details are given about it. A recent presentation shared on SlideShare covers various aspects of cryptography, including the history and evolution of cryptography, modern cryptographic techniques, and their applications in the current digital landscape. The presentation provides a comprehensive overview of cryptography, its history, and its practical applications, making it a valuable resource for anyone interested in learning more about the field of cryptography and its importance in securing digital communication.
